title: A Flexible Framework for Understanding the Dynamics of Evolving RDF Datasets

author: Yannis Roussakis, Foundation for Research and Technology - Hellas (FORTH)

segmentation: Hi everyone, thank you all for the introduction.
I'm going through psyches.
I come from the Institute of Computer Science in 4th and today I will present you our joint work which is a flexible framework for understanding the dynamics of evolving RDF datasets.
As you all know, later linked open data datasets are constantly evolving.
Such evolution comes from the inclusion of new experimental evidence, the correction of erroneous conceptualizations, and many other observations.
As a result, the detection and analysis of the differences between datasets is very crucial.
There are cases where where we want to observe their synchronization of autonomously developed versions.
We want the visualization of the evolution history of a data set, or there are cases where we want the synchronization of interconnecting linked open data datasets.
In this slide, we see that we use datasets to store and represent.
Information from real world settings.
Such settings constantly evolve and change overtime for several reasons, and this causes a huge impact on the datasets themselves.
As a result, our work.
Comes to to answering questions such as which changes occur, how to detect, and how to represent them.
So the main contribution of our work is a framework for detecting and analyzing changes and evolution, history of linked open data datasets.
The key features of our framework is the change definition in which we have different change types with respect to the domain of expertise.
The change detection using an efficient change detection algorithm, and the change representation which is mainly based on ontologies and allows the querying spanning multiple versions.
Considering both changes in the data.
